awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Motion Assisted Hand Exoskeleton with Virtual Reality (MAVHEXO) for Post Stroke Rehabilitation
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Technology Transfer Phase I project will realize a sensorized soft robotic hand exoskeleton coupled with an interactive 3D virtual reality (VR) gaming environment that provides fine motor training for stroke patients' hands. There is a currently a lack of available devices that provide fine sensory and motor training of the hand. The potential benefit is to fill this niche market opportunity, especially when considering the high incidence of hand disability due to stroke and other neuromusculoskeletal injuries. This system can provide structured therapy sessions which requires minimal therapist supervision while improving patient engagement which enhances the broader participation. As a complimentary technology for current rehabilitation practice, it has a potential to lower health care and labor costs associated with neurological rehabilitation. The outpatient physical rehabilitation market is a $30 billion industry growing at a rate of 7% in the US, mainly due to the growing elderly population. The robot-assisted rehabilitation market is expected to grow dramatically, reaching $2 billion by 2020. As robot-assisted treatment becomes widely available, the customer base will grow from acute care clinics to long-term rehabilitation centers and finally to home-based care. 

The intellectual merit of this project results from the combination of a soft robotic system with fine motor control synced to VR games for both sensory and motor stimuli. The robotic exoskeleton provides individual joint control to practice complex grasping while the VR environment provides targeted rehabilitation games. This system addresses the fine motor control needs that have not been met by current hand rehabilitation devices, which only offer gross motions. Adaptive algorithms will adjust to the patient's level of ability to accomplish the assigned tasks in virtual game scenarios, providing accessibility for a wide range of population with different levels of severity. There are three main goals for the project. First, we will develop a VR environment simulating real-world hand motion via interaction with objects in an immersive game. Second, we will develop adaptive control algorithms for the soft robotic exoskeleton to provide active assistive motion in performing rehabilitation-oriented tasks in the VR environment. Third, a pilot study will be conducted with both healthy individuals and hand-impaired stroke patients. The Phase I project will produce a system with assistive hand motion in a targeted rehabilitation virtual game environment, which can be tested for efficacy in a larger clinical population of stroke survivors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Motion Assisted Hand Exoskeleton with Virtual Reality (MAVHEXO) for Post Stroke Rehabilitation

 

The focus of the Motion Assisted Hand Exoskeleton with Virtual Reality (MAVHEXO) was to develop an immersive virtual game that integrates with a motion assisting soft-exoskeleton glove for post-stroke rehabilitation.

Although a few gaming based hand rehabilitation devices are commercially available, their motion capabilities are inadequate for training functional grasping. Many of them are passive devices, which do not provide assisted motion and only record movements. Some devices provide flexion and extension through end effectors, which prohibit grasping related activities. To achieve full functional recovery of the hand, an ideal system would aid patients with a limited initial capacity for voluntary motion while training various grasping modes in 3D space with fine motor control.

The research supported by this grant helped the integration of an assistive robotic hand exoskeleton with the virtual 3D game providing an immersive therapy environment for patients to work on fine motor rehab as well as develop cognitive skills through the motor and sensory stimuli. Various grasping techniques were implemented that correspond to real-world actions that the user, as viewed through a head-mounted display. The robotic exoskeleton provides active assistance to patients to help complete a task with the help of sensors and a pneumatic system driven by a hybrid force-position control algorithm.

A study was conducted with six healthy individuals, with each participant playing the virtual game twice that is Trail 1 and Trail 2. From the initial testing, the healthy users found the VR environment to be intuitive and easy to pick up items using the soft hand exoskeleton and were successful in the first attempt. Although, there was a learning curve with a longer time duration spent for Trial 1 than for Trial 2.  The active assist function of the exoskeleton performed reliably, where the system was set to move to an active assist model after a few seconds of hand inactivity during a task.

Stroke remains a leading cause of partial or full loss of sensory and motor function, with the majority of stroke survivors failing to regain functional use of their paretic hand. Approximately 65% of patients at six months cannot incorporate their paretic hand effectively into daily activities.

The immersive VR environment helps engage and focus in rehabilitation while motivating patients to participate in skill training that can transfer to the real world. The various grasp techniques, along with visual, auditory, and haptic feedback, provide the necessary feedback required for proprioception, especially in patients who have suffered a stroke and have weak or completely lost sense of proprioception due to their incident. The soft robotic exoskeleton can help the user to perform continuous passive motion and active assist motion with a repeatable, precise, and reliable manner.
